newsitem.title: USA: Gold producer downturn seen creating opportunities.
newsitem.headline: Gold producer downturn seen creating opportunities.

text.p: Negative investor sentiment towards gold-mining companies could create buying opportunities, a fund manager said on Monday.

Suzanne Killea, a portfolio manager with Franklin Templeton which has $450 million invested in gold assets, said investor sentiment towards gold producers "is less than robust now. The Busang saga has really put a pall on the entire sector".
She was referring to the Busang deposit in Indonesia, discovered by Canada's Bre-X Minerals Ltd.
The company at one time put gold reserves at 71 million ounces, which would have made it the biggest gold find this century.

But preliminary tests by Bre-X's partner Freeport McMoran Copper and Gold Inc indicated the property might contain "insignificant" amounts of gold. The announcement prompted heavy selling of Bre-X shares last month.

"We've seen a re-rating occurring across the board, most principally affecting exploration and junior (mining companies)," Killea said at Platt's Metals Week 1997 precious metals conference in San Francisco.
"I think we are going to continue to see a shift towards the established producers," she said.

Killea said sentiment over the next few months would remain negative. "It may take until the third quarter this year to see investors return to the sector...which actually creates buying opportunities. I think we are starting to see good value found across all the sectors," she said.

"To some extent investors have thrown the baby out with the bath water and therefore either the investors with cash and patience and/or the majors with cash and patience will see some great buying opportunities," she said.

"I think the companies with positive cash flow and cash could potentially pick up some low-cost ounces in the juniors and exploratory (companies). You'll probably see a bit of M&A (merger and acquisition) work coming out in the second half of this year and possibly into 1998," she said.
"The juniors that have cash in their coffers and are able to add value through reserve additions and potentially moving into production should also see good value for the investors," she said.
Killea said her forecast was "to position the fund for again the trading band that I had last year which was roughly $350 to $375 an ounce... basically a stable gold price."

Firoze Katrak, vice-president of business consulting at Charles River Associates Inc, told the conference he forecast a gold price range of between $300 and $375 an ounce until 1999. He forecast a higher gold price after 1999 but did not give a figure.
